body.p: We are writing to present a short case that we believe might be of interest to the Aesthetic Surgery Journal readership. Necrotizing fasciitis remains one of the most life-threatening soft tissue infections, and a patient presented to us with this infection following calf augmentation. 1

In 2011, a 26-year-old man presented to our hospital 2 days after cosmetic calf augmentation with implants, complaining of a fever and pain when standing or walking. He had no allergies and no significant past medical history. The initial augmentation procedure was performed by a private surgeon in an accredited center; 105-mL, symmetrical-base, smooth-surface silicone implants were placed in the retromuscular plane. No other procedures were performed concurrently. The patient did not provide information about which antibiotic prophylaxis (if any) was administered. Discharge instructions included rest, low-molecular-weight heparin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs but did not include antibiotics.

Physical examination upon presentation to our clinic revealed skin tenderness in the legs and pain upon palpation, along with erythema and blisters containing serous fluid (Figure 1). The patient was clinically unstable with a temperature of 39.5°C, pulse of 113 bpm, and blood pressure of 86/54 mm Hg. Laboratory tests revealed a white blood cell count of 1.8 × 109/L, hemoglobin level of 12.6 g/dL, and increased C-reactive protein (202 mg/L), creatinine (203 µmol/L), bilirubin (219 µmol/L), and creatine kinase (14499 U/L). Platelet count was 49 × 109/L. Coagulation parameters were also altered (activated partial thromboplastin time, 42.3 seconds; international normalized ratio, 3). A computed tomography scan showed inflammation in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, along with gas (Figure 2).

caption.p: Two days after calf augmentation with 105-mL symmetrical smooth silicone implants in the retromuscular plane, the patient developed multiorgan failure and presented to the emergency room. He had erythema and blistering of the legs.

(A) The axial computed tomography image of the medial third of the patient’s legs shows inflammation in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, along with gas. (B) This 3-dimensional reconstruction shows the placement of the implants.

body.p: A clinical diagnosis of necrotizing fasciitis was made, and treatment commenced with meropenem, clindamycin, and penicillin. The implant devices were removed and extensive surgical debridement was performed for the involved skin, fascia, and muscle. Cultures showed Enterococcus faecalis and Candida albicans, so the patient was prescribed a course of clindamycin, linezolid, and anidulafungin for 14 days. It is important to note that E faecalis is an uncommon cause and is usually associated with enteric perforation. 2 Candidal necrotizing soft tissue infections are extremely uncommon in immunocompetent patients. 3

Surgical debridement was repeated, for a total of 3 procedures. Histologic evaluation showed necrosis of the fascia and the muscle, polymorphonuclear infiltration, thrombosis of the microvessels, and liquefaction of the subcutaneous tissue. Two weeks later, the condition was controlled and the wounds were closed with skin grafts. The patient was discharged after 24 days. He recovered completely, and there were no long-term complications except skin scarring, which can be seen in Figure 3.

caption.p: After 2 months, the patient had recovered and the wounds were closed. Aside from scarring, there were no other long-term complications.

body.p: Calf augmentation with silicone implants is generally considered a safe and aesthetically pleasing procedure with few side effects, 4 but it is still important for surgeons to be aware of potential postoperative infections such as the one described in this Letter to the Editor. To our knowledge, this is the first report of necrotizing fasciitis following calf augmentation. In our patient, early diagnosis and treatment were critical for survival.
